abstract: pmc Sci Rep Sci Rep 1579 scirep Scientific Reports 2045-2322 Nature Publishing Group PMC12480838 PMC12480838.1 12480838 12480838 41023009 10.1038/s41598-025-18864-4 18864 1 Article The masking effects of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction on the association between childhood trauma and postpartum depressive symptoms: a cross-sectional study Wang Yanchi 1 2 3 Huang Wei 2 Xu Xujuan xxj_1124@126.com 3 Gu Jian gujianntu@163.com 2 1 https://ror.org/006teas31 grid.39436.3b 0000 0001 2323 5732 Affiliated Nantong Hospital of Shanghai University (The Sixth People’s Hospital of Nantong), 2 https://ror.org/02afcvw97 grid.260483.b 0000 0000 9530 8833 Nantong University, 3 https://ror.org/001rahr89 grid.440642.0 0000 0004 0644 5481 Affiliated Hospital of Nantong University, 29 9 2025 2025 15 478255 33598 13 1 2025 4 9 2025 29 09 2025 01 10 2025 01 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Adequate mental health underlies individuals’ overall well-being. This study aims to probe the relationship between childhood trauma and postpartum depressive symptoms among women and dissect the mediating roles of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction, and endeavors to supply pragmatic directives for precluding and taking remedial action on postpartum depression. The study was conducted from December 2023 to June 2024 at the postpartum clinics of three representative tertiary hospitals in Nantong City, with the participants being mothers undergoing their 42-day postpartum check-up. Participants completed the childhood trauma questionnaire (CTQ), the Edinburgh postnatal depression scale (EPDS), the general self-efficacy scale (GSES), and the marital satisfaction scale (MSS). Using SPSS 27.0 and the process macro (Model 4), our parallel mediation analysis revealed that self-efficacy and marital satisfaction acted as masking mediators. These mediators accounted for 64.0% and 133.3% of the total effect, respectively (absolute values), indicating suppression effects. Importantly, the explanatory value of the integrated model lies in its ability to simultaneously assess both pathways, showing how these mediators jointly influence the association between childhood trauma and postpartum depression. This study clarifies the complex relationships among childhood trauma, self-efficacy, marital satisfaction, and postpartum depressive symptoms. Identifying self-efficacy and marital satisfaction as masking mediators offers crucial guidance for PPD prevention and intervention, supplying targeted evidence for alleviating postpartum depressive symptoms by strengthening the former two. It holds significant reference value for comprehensive measures to boost the mental health and well-being of postpartum women and their families. Keywords Childhood trauma Postpartum depressive symptoms Self-efficacy Marital satisfaction Mediation analysis Subject terms Depression Post-traumatic stress disorder The scientific research projects of Nantong Commission of Health QN2023043 Wang Yanchi pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © Springer Nature Limited 2025 Introduction Postpartum Depression (PPD) is a pervasive and grave mental health concern that casts a wide net of consequences on mothers and their families 1 2 3 4 5 5 6 7 8 9 10 11 12 13 PPD is a multifaceted condition influenced by a range of biological 1 6 14 15 16 17 18 20 21 22 23 24 25 26 27 30 28 29 30 27 Self-efficacy, defined as an individual’s belief and perception of their ability to successfully perform a particular behavior, plays a crucial role in a mother’s postpartum experience 31 32 33 34 35 36 Marital satisfaction is also a significant factor in postpartum mental health. According to attachment theory, a secure attachment style is associated with higher marital satisfaction and better mental health 37 38 39 40 41 40 In conclusion, the study aims to uncover the connection tying childhood trauma to postpartum depressive symptoms and examine the mediatory contributions of self-efficacy along with marital satisfaction. Through the in-depth discussions and analyses presented earlier, we have formulated the hypothesized model (Fig. 1 Fig. 1 Hypothetical model of this study. Methods Participants The study was conducted between December 2023 and June 2024 at three major tertiary hospitals in Nantong City, specifically in their postpartum clinics. The study involved women attending their 42-day postpartum health assessments. The 42-day postpartum assessment was selected based on empirical evidence and policy considerations: (1) this period represents a critical biological and psychological transition phase, with physiological recovery and maternal role adaptation converging, during which depressive symptoms often emerge or intensify 1 42 43 44 Measures Basic information survey The basic information survey, crafted by our research group, aimed to gather critical data, encompassing two main areas: (1) key demographic details such as maternal age, education level, and residential location, and (2) factors pertinent to maternity, including the number of previous pregnancies, any history of miscarriages, use of fertility treatments, and complications encountered during pregnancy. Childhood trauma questionnaire-short form (CTQ-SF) The CTQ-SF, a recognized tool for assessing childhood trauma and abuse experiences, consists of 28 items across five categories 45 46 Edinburgh postnatal depression scale (EPDS) The EPDS, which was developed by Cox et al. 47 48 49 50 50 Chinese version of the general self-efficacy scale (GSES) The GSES, which was formulated by Schwarzer 51 52 Marital satisfaction scale (MSS) The MSS is part of Olson’s ENRICH Marital Quality Questionnaire developed by Olson et al. 53 54 Ethics Ethical approval for this study was granted by the Ethics Committee of the Affiliated Hospital of Nantong University. The approval reference number assigned is 2022-K150-01. All procedures involved in this research were carried out in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Clinical trial number: not applicable. At the outset of the questionnaire, participants were given a comprehensive understanding of the study’s objectives. It was emphasized that taking part in the survey was optional, and the confidentiality, privacy, and anonymity of the respondents were assured. The participants were made aware of their right to withdraw from the study whenever they wished, and they were assured that doing so would not lead to any adverse outcomes. The research team pledged that the collected data would be kept confidential and used solely for research purposes. Statistical analysis For measurement data that conform to the normal distribution, they are described by mean ± SD. For measurement data that do not conform to the normal distribution, they are described by median and quartiles. And for categorical data, they are described by frequency or proportion. The Mann–Whitney U-test and the Kruskal–Wallis H-test were used to examine the differences in postpartum depressive symptoms among different groups. Pearson’s correlation analysis was engaged to dissect the correlation among variables. We used multiple linear regression to assess the independent effects of childhood trauma, self-efficacy, and marital satisfaction on postpartum depressive symptoms while controlling for potential confounders. This method allows for the assessment of each predictor’s unique contribution to the outcome, adjusting for other variables that may influence the relationship. Harman’s single-factor test was used to test the common method bias 55 P Results Characteristics of the study population Data on general characteristics, namely the maternal age, education level, husband education level, residence, family monthly income, gestational week of abortion history, feeding pattern, delivery mode, parity, and assisted reproduction, were collected (Table 1 P 2 Table 1 Characteristics of the subjects enrolled in this study. The prevalence of specific traumatic experiences within this group is as follows: emotional neglect was reported by 130 participants (20.8%), physical neglect by 141 (22.6%), emotional abuse by 6 (1.0%), physical abuse by 4 (0.6%), and sexual abuse by 23 (3.7%). Mediation analysis The mediating role of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction between childhood trauma on postpartum depressive symptoms is illustrated in Fig. 2 57 58 5 Fig. 2 Mediating role of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction between childhood trauma on postpartum depressive symptoms. * P P P Table 5 Tests of mediating effects of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction (incompletely standardized indirect effect(s) of X on Y). Effect Boot SE 95 percent confidence interval Indirect effects/ direct effects Boot LLCI Boot ULCI Total effect 0.0517 0.0197 0.0130 0.0905 Direct effect − 0.0531 0.0212 − 0.0948 − 0.0114 Total indirect effect 0.1048 0.0132 0.0798 0.1321 Childhood trauma → self-efficacy → postpartum depressive symptoms 0.0340 0.0090 0.0171 0.0524 64.0% Childhood trauma → marital satisfaction → postpartum depressive symptoms 0.0708 0.0123 0.0479 0.0958 133.3% C1 − 0.0368 0.0171 − 0.0719 − 0.0036 Discussion The present study explores the complex relationship between childhood trauma and postpartum depressive symptoms, with a focus on the mediating roles of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction. Our findings reveal that these two factors act as masking mediators, highlighting the multifaceted nature of postpartum depression. While childhood trauma is a known risk factor for mental health issues in adulthood, its weak correlation with postpartum depression suggests that it alone cannot fully explain the development of this condition. Instead, postpartum depression appears to be influenced by a combination of biological, psychological, and social factors. Our mediation analysis suggests that the relationship between childhood trauma and postpartum depression may be influenced by indirect pathways, such as self-efficacy and marital satisfaction. Identifying these mediators is crucial for developing targeted interventions. Therefore, a broader exploration of contributing factors, including cultural perspectives, is necessary to enrich our understanding of these complex relationships. The roles of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction as mediators are of crucial significance. Self-efficacy, being an individual’s belief in their ability to perform specific behaviors, is a powerful determinant of a mother’s postpartum experience 59 60 61 62 63 64 A fulfilling marriage provides a solid foundation of emotional support, practical help, and a sense of belonging 65 66 67 68 69 30 70 71 The masking effect observed in this study is truly intriguing and holds several possible explanations. Self-efficacy and marital satisfaction may indeed act as protective factors that counterbalance the negative impact of childhood trauma. A mother with high self-efficacy may be able to draw on her internal resources and coping strategies more effectively 72 73 74 Our findings have significant implications for clinical practice and intervention. Cultural factors, such as societal expectations of motherhood, support systems, and attitudes towards mental health, may influence the relationship between childhood trauma and postpartum depression. For example, strong family support systems in some cultures may mitigate the impact of childhood trauma, while stigma around mental health issues in other cultures may exacerbate symptoms. Future research should explore these cultural nuances to provide a more comprehensive understanding. Healthcare practitioners should be aware of the potential effects of childhood trauma on the mental health of postpartum women. Routine care for expectant and new mothers should include systematic checks for prior trauma experiences. Interventions aimed at enhancing self-efficacy and promoting healthy marital relationships can be highly effective in preventing and treating postpartum depression, especially for those with a history of childhood trauma. Education and support programs can help mothers develop and strengthen their self-efficacy, while couples counseling and support groups can improve marital satisfaction and address underlying relationship issues. In conclusion, this study provides valuable insights into the complex relationships between childhood trauma, postpartum depressive symptoms, self-efficacy, and marital satisfaction. The masking mediating effects of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction highlight the importance of considering multiple factors when addressing postpartum depression. Future research should further investigate the mechanisms underlying these effects to develop more targeted and effective interventions, ultimately improving the mental health of postpartum women and promoting family well-being. There exist multiple limitations in this study that merit attention. Firstly, the study was carried out in the postpartum clinics of just three tertiary hospitals situated in Nantong City. The individuals involved in the study were mothers who were having their routine 42-day postpartum check-ups. This relatively small and specific sample may not be fully representative of all postpartum women, and the results may not generalize to other populations or settings. Secondly, the cross-sectional design of the study does not allow for causal inferences. Future longitudinal studies should adopt prospective cohort designs tracking participants from pregnancy (e.g., third trimester) through multiple postpartum assessments (e.g., 42 days, 3 months, 6 months) to capture dynamic risk factor accumulation and establish temporal causality. Thirdly, the familiarity of the questionnaire administrators with the study’s objectives and procedures might have influenced participants’ responses. Future studies should use blinded administrators or provide additional training to ensure neutral and unbiased questionnaire delivery. Fourth, although delivery mode and feeding pattern are clinically relevant and may influence postpartum mental health in some contexts, our analysis did not find significant associations between these variables and postpartum depressive symptoms. Future studies with larger sample sizes or different populations may explore these associations further. Finally, we recognize that our study’s focus on marital satisfaction as a mediator, rather than directly measuring adult attachment styles, may limit the depth of our understanding of the underlying mechanisms. Future research should consider incorporating measures of adult attachment styles to provide a more nuanced exploration of the pathways linking childhood trauma to postpartum depression. Conclusion In conclusion, this study has illuminated the intricate relationship between childhood trauma and postpartum depressive symptoms and highlighted the masking mediating roles of self-efficacy and marital satisfaction. Our findings underscore the significance of considering these factors in understanding and addressing postpartum depression. Childhood trauma poses a risk, but self-efficacy and marital satisfaction can act as buffers, potentially altering the trajectory of postpartum mental health. This research has important implications for clinical practice, emphasizing the need for screening and targeted interventions to enhance self-efficacy and improve marital relationships, ultimately promoting the well-being of postpartum women and their families. Future research should build on these findings to further refine our understanding and develop more effective preventive and treatment strategies.
